articleContent.title: Arpeggio: 9th in E (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Arpeggio: 9th in E
An arpeggio is when the notes of a chord are played individually instead of strummed or plucked together. In this case, we are looking at the 9th arpeggio in the key of E.

## Notes and Intervals
- E (Root)
- F# (Major 2nd)
- G# (Major 3rd)
- B (Perfect 5th)
- D# (Major 7th)
- F# (Major 2nd) - An octave higher than the previous F#
- G# (Major 3rd) - An octave higher than the previous G#
- B (Perfect 5th) - An octave higher than the previous B
- D# (Major 7th) - An octave higher than the previous D#

## Genre and Musical Flavor
This arpeggio in E can be frequently found in genres like jazz, fusion, and neo-soul. The 9th arpeggio gives a jazzy and sophisticated flavor to the music. It is often used to add color and richness to chord progressions. The dissonance created by the major 7th interval (D#) adds a sense of tension and release, contributing to the overall harmonic complexity.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the 9th arpeggio in E:
1. "Spain" by Chick Corea - This jazz fusion classic prominently features arpeggios and showcases the harmonic richness of the 9th arpeggio.
2. "I Wish" by Stevie Wonder - This funk/soul hit incorporates jazzy elements including arpeggios with extended chords, including the 9th arpeggio in E.
3. "Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock - A jazz standard that highlights the use of arpeggios and extended chords, including the 9th arpeggio, in a funky and groovy context.
